Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: Harnessing the Power of Herbaria to Understand the Changing Flora of California: A Biodiversity Hotspot in Peril
Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this project is to compile and provide information (e.g., species name, location, habitat, and flowering time) from California-collected vascular plant specimens held at 19 herbaria in California and at Harvard University (repository of many older California specimens). The plants targeted are those that dominate California habitats and those most imperiled by threats to biodiversity (including climate change). Specimen information will be available online at the Consortium of California Herbaria (CCH) Web portal (http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/consortium). The project will also accomplish the seamless provision of data on California plants held by the museums of SEINet (Southwest Environmental Information Network) via the CCH web site as a step toward building regional and national consortia.

This project provides tangible benefits to the public, students of all levels, and the research community. Specimen data will be downloadable so that anyone can use the information to pursue interests and questions (e.g., understanding current plant distributions, identifying plants of a particular place, predicting future plant migrations). Undergraduate students will be involved extensively with data entry, providing them with skills and training applicable to future professional pursuits. This project is a major step toward building a United States virtual plant museum that provides information on the distribution of plants nationwide.

The images and digitized data from this project will be integrated into the online national resource as outlined in the community strategic plan available at http://digbiocol.files.wordpress.com/2010/05/digistratplanfinaldraft.pdf.

POR.DRECONTENT:
California is a global ‘biodiversity hotspot,’ with a rich and highly endemic flora. The state’s native flora numbers over 6,500 species, subspecies, and varieties; over 2,300 (33%) are endemic. This diverse and highly endemic flora is also highly endangered. The all too familiar forces of habitat destruction and fragmentation, urban and suburban sprawl, and natural resource exploitation have impacted the state’s flora severely. The California Native Plant Society includes about 1/3 of native species on its ranked lists of plants of special conservation concern (http://cnps.web.aplus.net/cgi-bin/inv/inventory.cgi), with half of these being in the two most endangered categories (i.e., categories 1A: plants presumed extinct in California + 1B: plants rare, threatened or endangered in California and elsewhere). In this context, anthropogenic climate change poses a heightened threat. The rising temperatures predicted by climate change models are already being observed in California and will impact the state’s plants as many species must shift their ranges to the north and/or to higher elevation to find suitable habitat.

Herbarium specimens that document the ranges of California’s native species are a rich source of distributional data that can be used to understand habitat requirements and thus to predict the effects of climate change and devise conservation strategies to reduce species loss. The power of herbarium specimen data to address these issues at large geographic scales has been significantly enhanced by two developments: (1) technological advances have facilitated computer databasing and internet dissemination of information gleaned from specimens; and (2) the formation of regional consortia that effectively pool the unique holdings of individual herbaria. This project carried out by the Consortium of California Herbaria (CCH) has capitalized on both of these developments. This project has built the quantity and quality of data about plants in the most floristically diverse region in the US, while simultaneously building capacity at herbaria in California and beyond.

With 21 original participating institutions involved in this project, major goals included: 

1. Build knowledge of the flora of California in support of the national effort to predict, understand and monitor the effects of climate change by:

--databasing >338,600 specimens of California plant taxa that are the ecological dominants in California habitats and those that are already imperiled;

--georeferencing all specimens of these same taxa, including specimens that are already databased and available through CCH but that have not yet been georeferenced (total = >500,000 specimens).

2. Advance the goals of the CCH and the formation of national herbaria consortia by initiating data sharing of California specimen records between the Harvard University Herbaria (HUH) and the CCH, and between SEINet and the CCH.

3. Extend, implement, and sustain informatics resources to accomplish the above, both for this proposal and to distribute broadly to the community to assist in other efforts.

The project has enabled the CCH to database and georeference several hundreds of thousands of specimens; indeed, as a result of this project the CCH web portal currently hosts over 2.2 million records from 37 participating institutions, of which more than 75% include latitude and longitude coordinates. A subaward (via supplement to the original grant) enabled selected participating institutions to digitize specimen records of rare, threatened, endangered, and endemic taxa of the California Floristic Province (CFP) in Baja California from four herbaria (CAS, RSA-POM, SBBG, UC) that are part of the CCH. 13,600 specimenswere databased and georeferenced and are now served on the CCH web portal. 

Through this project the CCH has the power to address questions of geographic distribution, habitat requirements, and associations among species and geographic and environmental parameters. Major portions of the immense data resource that is held in California herbaria are now directly available for use by anyone with internet access. The CCH site is actively used by biologists who study plants and who have roles in plant identification (e.g., herbarium staff, consulting biologists), and by local, state and federal agency personnel, conservation biologists, and policy makers. The enriched CCH dataset has strengthened the baseline against which future change in the flora can be measured, and has enabled researchers to track the impact of climate change.

The project has provided important training in museum informatics to more than twenty undergraduate and graduate students at participating institutions. Attention has been given to recruiting students from underrepresented groups. All have learned data entry and georeferencing along with learning a great deal about curating herbarium specimens. Through this project we have also implemented new tools and strategies in georeferencing and have shared these among participating herbaria. We continue to offer georeferencing workshops and training sessions to curatorial staff and to incoming undergraduate interns each semester.
